solutions.title: solution-using-awk-beats-100-of-submissions-0ms-solution
solutions.content:
I would definitely recommend this tutorial: http://www.grymoire.com/Unix/Awk.html if you'd like to know more about GAWK/NAWK. Similar to sed, awk is used to perform complex editing tasks to streams of text. The main difference is that awk is more suitable for larger editing tasks (those that may need some programming language features).

Solution :
```
wordcount=$(head -1 file.txt | wc -w)
col_n=1
while [[ $col_n -le $wordcount ]]; do
	awk "{ print \$$col_n }" file.txt | paste -sd " "
	col_n=$((col_n + 1))
done
```

Here're some quick notes to help you understand:

The code block with an "END" prefix is only executed after the last line is read; similarly, a code block with a "BEGIN" prefix will be executed before any line reads.

AWK is line-based: the main code block (the code block without prefix) processes one line of input at a time.

	awk "{ print \$$col_n }" file.txt | paste -sd " "
	col_n=$((col_n + 1))
done
```

    #!/bin/bash

    col=1
    row=1
    
    while read line; do
        col=1
        for word in $line; do
                matrix[$row,$col]=$word
                ((col++))
        done
        ((row++))
    done < file.txt

        echo -n ${matrix[1,$i]} 
        for((j=2;j<row;j++)) do
                echo -n ' '${matrix[$j,$i]}
        done
        echo
    done

solutions.title: bash-two-solutions-awk-bash
solutions.content:
The first solution is to use `awk` in which we define an arrary whose `i`th element represents the `i`th column of the input. 

Implementation (8ms, 81.24%): 
```
awk '
{
    for (i = 1; i <= NF; i++) {
        s[i] = s[i]?s[i] FS $i:$i
    }
}
END {
    for (i in s) {
        print s[i]
    }
}' file.txt
```

The 2nd solution is to use pure bash in which we define array `arr` whose `i`th element stores the `i`th column of input. 

Implementation (144ms, 5.16%): 
```
declare -a arr

while IFS= read -r line
do
    i=0
    for word in $line
    do
        [[ ${arr[$i]} ]] && arr[$i]="${arr[$i]} $word" || arr[$i]=$word
        ((i++))
    done
done < file.txt

for ((i=0; i < ${#arr[@]}; i++))
do
    echo ${arr[i]}
done
```

Clearly the 1st solution is superior since it is dramtically faster and shorter. Here, bash has an unpleasant fact that in range-based for loop an element with more than one word would be displayed in many lines, e.g.  

```
arr=(apple "passion fruit" banana)

for ele in ${arr[@]}
do
    echo $ele
done
```
outputs below in which `passion` and `fruit` are on two lines. 
```
apple
passion
fruit
banana
```

        s[i] = s[i]?s[i] FS $i:$i
    }

    }
}' file.txt
```

```
# Read from the file file.txt and print its transposed content to stdout.
declare -A transposed
nrows=0
ncols=0
while read -r -a row; do
    for ((i = 0; i < ${#row[@]}; i++)); do
        transposed[$i,$nrows]=${row[i]}
    done
    ((nrows++))
    ncols=${#row[@]}
done < file.txt

for ((r = 0; r < ncols; r++)); do
    sep=
    for ((c = 0; c < nrows; c++)); do
        printf '%s%s' "$sep" "${transposed[$r,$c]}"
        sep=" "
    done
    printf '\n'
done
```

awk-gets-the-job-done
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
When approaching this problem, the first thing that comes to mind is finding a way to swap the rows and columns of the file content. To achieve this, we need to think about how to read the file and store its content in a way that allows for easy transposition. We can then output the transposed content to the console or another file.
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
To solve this problem, we will use the `awk` command-line utility, which is a powerful tool for text processing.

In the code, we start by defining an awk script enclosed in single quotes. The script consists of two parts: the main code block and the `END` block.

In the main code block, we iterate over each line of the input file using the default behavior of awk. For each line, we use a for loop to iterate over the fields `$i` separated by whitespace. We then store each field in the array `a` with the column index `i` and the row index `NR`, which represents the current line number.

After processing all the lines, we move to the `END` block. Here, we iterate over the array `a` by nested for loops. The outer loop iterates over the columns `i`, and the inner loop iterates over the rows `j`. We use the `printf` statement to print the transposed content by accessing the elements of the array with the indices `a[i, j]`. We add the appropriate separators (`RS` for the end of a row and `FS` for the space between elements) to format the output correctly.

Finally, we execute the `awk` command by passing the input file `file.txt` as an argument. The transposed content is then printed to the standard output `stdout`.

Using `awk` allows us to efficiently read and process the file, store the content in an array, and print the transposed result.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(n)$$, where $$n$$ represents the total number of elements in the input file. This is because we need to iterate over each line and each field in the file to store them in the array. The nested loops in the `END` block also contribute to the linear time complexity.
- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
$$O(n)$$ because we need to store the content of the input file in the array `a`. The size of the array depends on the number of elements in the file, which is directly proportional to the space complexity. The additional space used by variables and temporary storage is negligible compared to the size of the input file.
# Runtime & Memory
![Screenshot 2023-09-08 at 11.52.36.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/f72741b1-5778-47f3-b2f9-eebced5848af_1694156608.758566.png)

# Code
```
# Read from the file file.txt and print its transposed content to stdout.
awk '
{
    for (i = 1; i <= NF; i++) {
        a[i, NR] = $i
    }
}
END {
    for (i = 1; i <= NF; i++) {
        for (j = 1; j <= NR; j++) {
            printf "%s%s", a[i, j], (j == NR ? RS : FS)
        }
    }
}
' file.txt
```

bash-no-awk-just-bash-arrays
solutions.content:
The best performimg solution to this problem use `awk`, but I wanted to see if I could to this using bash arrays instead.

It possible, but it's not pretty...

# Code
```
input="file.txt"
declare -a lines=()

rows=$((0))

# Read the input into an array
# bash does not seem to support 2D arrays
# so it's just 1D
while IFS=' ' read -a line
do
  columns=${#line[@]}
  rows=$(($rows + 1))
  lines=(${lines[@]} ${line[@]})
done < "$input"


# Index into the array to transpose it
# building output line by line
for ((c = 0; c < $columns; c++ ))
do
  line=${lines[$c]}
  for ((r = 1; r < $rows; r++)) do
    line="$line ${lines[$(($c + $r * $columns))]}"
  done
  echo $line
done
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

1. This script uses awk, a text processing tool, to read the contents of the file and transpose them. Here's how it works:

2. For each field in each row of the input file, it stores the field in an array a with indices i (column) and NR (row number).

3. After reading the entire file, it loops over the columns and rows of the array a, printing each element separated by a space. When it reaches the end of a row, it prints a newline character.


# Complexity

1. Reading the file into a 2D array takes O(NM) time and O(NM) space, where N is the number of rows in the file, M is the number of columns in the file, and we assume that each field is of constant length.

2. Transposing the array takes O(NM) time and O(NM) space, since we are constructing a new 2D array with dimensions M x N.

3. Printing the transposed array takes O(N*M) time and O(1) space, since we are just printing each element once.
- Time complexity: O(NM)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: O(NM)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code

# Read from the file file.txt and print its transposed content to stdout.
awk '{for (i=1; i<=NF; i++) {a[i,NR]=$i}} END {for (i=1; i<=NF; i++) {for (j=1; j<=NR; j++) {printf("%s",a[i,j]); if (j!=NR) printf(" ");} printf("\n")}}' file.txt

```

solutions.title: 194-transpose-file
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
The task is to transpose the given text file, which means we need to convert the rows of the file to columns and vice versa.

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
One way to approach this problem is to use a bash script that reads the text file line by line, splits each line using the space delimiter, and stores the values in an array. Then, we can use another loop to iterate over the columns and store them in a separate array. Finally, we can print the transposed content of the file by iterating over the columns and printing each row.

# Algorithm
Read the text file line by line using a loop
For each line, split the line using the space delimiter and store the values in an array
Use another loop to iterate over the columns and store them in a separate array
Finally, print the transposed content of the file by iterating over the columns and printing each row

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
The time complexity of this approach is O(m*n), where m is the number of rows and n is the number of columns in the text file. This is because we need to read each line of the file and split it into an array of n elements

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
The space complexity of this approach is also O(m*n) because we need to store the entire contents of the file in an array of m rows and n columns. However, since we are transposing the content of the file, we only need to store the transpose of the file, which means we can optimize the space complexity by storing only n rows and m columns.
# Code
```
# Read from the file file.txt and print its transposed content to stdout.
awk '{ for(i=1; i<=NF; i++) { a[i,NR]=$i; } } END { for(i=1; i<=NF; i++) { printf("%s", a[i,1]); for(j=2; j<=NR; j++) { printf(" %s", a[i,j]); } printf("\n"); } }' file.txt

```
This command reads the content of file.txt and creates an array a to store the values. The first loop for(i=1; i<=NF; i++) iterates over the columns and rows of the file, and assigns the value of each field to the corresponding position in the array (a[i,NR]=$i). The second loop for(i=1; i<=NF; i++) iterates over the columns of the array, and prints the values of each row in transposed order (printf("%s", a[i,1]); for(j=2; j<=NR; j++) { printf(" %s", a[i,j]); } printf("\n");).

The time complexity of this solution is O(mn), where m is the number of rows and n is the number of columns in the file. The space complexity is also O(mn), since the entire file is stored in the a array.

awk '{ for(i=1; i<=NF; i++) { a[i,NR]=$i; } } END { for(i=1; i<=NF; i++) { printf("%s", a[i,1]); for(j=2; j<=NR; j++) { printf(" %s", a[i,j]); } printf("\n"); } }' file.txt

```

solutions.title: solution-using-awk
concise-and-easy-solution-using-temporary-files
solutions.content:
# Intuition
Read file line by line, transform each line into a column (multiple lines) and save column somewhere for later. At the end combine all columns.

# Approach
Each line from file is piped to `tr`, which transforms the line to a column by replacing spaces with line breaks. These lines are saved to a temporary file, whose name is remembered in `columnFiles` variable.
After reading all lines from input file, `paste` combines column-files side-by-side.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
$$O(n + m)$$, where `n` is the number of lines in input file (for reading input); `m` is the number of columns in input file (for combining columns).

- Space complexity:
$$O(n)$$ memory space, where `n` is a number of lines in input file. The variable holding names of column-files grows with the number of lines (lines are transformed to columns).
$$O(n)$$ disk space, where `n` is the size of input file. Solution effectively makes a copy of input file, but splitted to chunks.

# Code
```
# Read from the file file.txt and print its transposed content to stdout.

# The idea is to transform each line in to a column (multiple lines)
# and save it to a separate file. Then combine all columns using `paste`
# command, which reads lines from multiple sources and outputs all
# that lines joined.

columnFiles=""

while read -r line
do
    columnFileName="$(mktemp)"
    # I use `tee` to save output to file because testing environment forbids output
    # redirections. 
    # The 'while read' cycle after `tee` suppresses tee's output, because, again,
    # no output redirections are allowed and 2>/dev/null is not available.
    echo "$line" | tr -s ' ' '\n' | tee  "$columnFileName" | while read -r suppressed; do true; done
    columnFiles="$columnFiles $columnFileName"
done <file.txt

paste -d ' ' $columnFiles
```
solutions.code:
```
# Read from the file file.txt and print its transposed content to stdout.

# The idea is to transform each line in to a column (multiple lines)
# and save it to a separate file. Then combine all columns using `paste`
# command, which reads lines from multiple sources and outputs all
# that lines joined.

columnFiles=""

while read -r line
do
    columnFileName="$(mktemp)"
    # I use `tee` to save output to file because testing environment forbids output
    # redirections. 
    # The 'while read' cycle after `tee` suppresses tee's output, because, again,
    # no output redirections are allowed and 2>/dev/null is not available.
    echo "$line" | tr -s ' ' '\n' | tee  "$columnFileName" | while read -r suppressed; do true; done
    columnFiles="$columnFiles $columnFileName"
done <file.txt

paste -d ' ' $columnFiles
```

solutions.title: just-builtins-one-file-pass
solutions.content:
Loop over lines, gather line items into successive array elements.  Dump the array afterwards.

Pure in-memory (filter-like) program: memory consumption is proportional to the file size.

```
# Read from the file file.txt and print its transposed content to stdout.
# Bash version, uses arrays.  One pass over the input file.

exec < file.txt

read -r z
l=($z)

while read -r z; do
    i=0
    for v in $z; do
            l[$i]+=" $v"
            ((i++))
    done
done

z=${#l[@]}
for ((i=0; i < $z; i++)); do
    echo "${l[$i]}"
done
```

# Read from the file file.txt and print its transposed content to stdout.
#!/bin/bash

columns=$(cat "file.txt" | awk -F ' ' END'{print NF}')
for i in $(seq 1 $columns)
do
output=$(cut -f $i -d ' ' "file.txt")
echo $output
done

solutions.title: very-detailed-solution-easy-to-understande
solutions.content:
# Intuition
First you need to know what's the number of columns?

# Approach
1) Using `wc` word count to count the number of lines and the number of words.
2) Given that the number of columns is the same in every line you can get the number of columns by `columns = words / lines`.
3) Iterate over each column to using `cut` with a `space` as delimiter with specifying the field number.
4) Using `tr` you can print the output in a single line by replacing the `newline` with the  `space`. 

# Code
```
#!/bin/bash
lines=$(cat file.txt |wc -l)
words=$(cat file.txt |wc -w)
columns=$(($words/$lines))

for (( i=1;i<=$columns;i++ ));
do
        echo $(cat file.txt | cut -d " " -f $i | tr '\n' ' ') 
done  
```

```bash

solutions.title: one-awk-sed-solution
solutions.content:
Treat file.txt as a table. firstly use awk to split tables by columns, for a centain colume, using sed to replace \n with a space (this action compare to altering a column of data to a row of data), then use sed to remove the trailing space. column by column.

```
#!/bin/bash

declare -i column
declare -i i

column=$(cat file.txt | awk 'NR==1 {print NF}')
i=1

while [[ $i -le $column ]] 
do 
    cat file.txt | awk '{print $'$i'}' | sed 's/\n/" "/' | sed 's/ $/\n/'
    let i+=1
done
```
solutions.code:
```
#!/bin/bash

declare -i column
declare -i i

column=$(cat file.txt | awk 'NR==1 {print NF}')
i=1

while [[ $i -le $column ]] 
do 
    cat file.txt | awk '{print $'$i'}' | sed 's/\n/" "/' | sed 's/ $/\n/'
    let i+=1
done
```

solutions.title: solution-with-cut-pure-bash-no-awk
solutions.content:
```
delimiter=' '
count=`head -n1 file.txt|grep -o "$delimiter" |wc -l`
for (( line = 1; line <= $((count+1)); line++ ))
do
        outLine=`cat file.txt|cut -d"$delimiter" -f$line |tr '\n' "$delimiter"`
        lineLen=`echo $outLine|wc --chars`
        echo $outLine |cut -c 1-$(($lineLen-1))
done
```

solutions.title: awk-solution-why-permission-denied
nothing-fancy-but-very-readable
solutions.content:
Looks like a lot of submissions here are focused on trying to make things shorter but the filp side it makes it obscure.

So here is a somewhat opposite approach - keep it readable.

The idea:

1. Calculate number of fields
2. in a for loop read the file and extract all values from column i into a line 

A couple notes:

1. awk adds a new line at the end, so the 'tr' command will replace new lines with spaces and the 'sed' command will remove the last space in each line.
2. the echo command will insert a new line between the lines.




```
fields=`head -1 file.txt | wc -w`
for i in `seq 1 $fields`
do 
    cat file.txt | awk "{print $"$i"}"  |tr '\r\n' ' ' |sed 's/ $//g'
    echo
done
```

solutions.title: ac-solution-with-question
efficient-matrix-transposition-with-awk
solutions.content:
# Intuition
When presented with the problem of transposing a matrix in the form of a file, one might first think of using nested loops: an outer loop for columns and an inner loop for rows. But with AWK, a powerful pattern scanning and processing language, we can perform the transposition in a more elegant manner.

# Approach
The script uses the power of associative arrays in AWK:
    We loop through each field in the input rows using for (i=1; i<=NF; i++). Here, NF represents the number of fields in the current record, essentially giving us the column count.
    Within this loop, we're building our associative array a. The key to this array is the column number i, and we're appending the current field value $i to this key. If a[i] already has a value, we append the new value with a space, otherwise, we simply set the new value.
    Once all rows have been processed, we enter the END block where we print out each value of our associative array a using for (i in a). This gives us the transposed matrix.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
 O(n\xD7m)O(n\xD7m) where nn is the number of rows and mm is the number of columns. We are effectively visiting each cell of the matrix once.

- Space complexity:
O(n\xD7m)O(n\xD7m) as we need to store the entire transposed matrix in memory.

# Code
```
awk '{for (i=1; i<=NF; i++) a[i]=a[i] ? a[i] " " $i : $i} END {for (i in a) print a[i]}' file.txt

```
solutions.code:
```
awk '{for (i=1; i<=NF; i++) a[i]=a[i] ? a[i] " " $i : $i} END {for (i in a) print a[i]}' file.txt

```

solutions.title: map-reduce-type-solution-with-awk
solutions.content:
A simple awk-heavy solution which first outputs every field with its field number, e.g.

```
1   name
2   age
1   alice
2   21
1   ryan
2   30
```

then does a stable sort (`sort -s`) on the field numbers, then combines them with awk again:

```
awk '{for (i=1;i<=NF;i++) print i, " ", $i}' file.txt \
   | sort -snk 1 \
   | awk 'BEGIN {i=1; start=1} {
	   if ($1 != i) {i = $1; printf "\n"; start=1}; 
	   if (start != 1) printf " "; 
	   printf "%s", $2; start=0}'
```
solutions.code:
```
1   name
2   age
1   alice
2   21
1   ryan
2   30
```

	   if ($1 != i) {i = $1; printf "\n"; start=1}; 
	   if (start != 1) printf " "; 
	   printf "%s", $2; start=0}'
```

Is O(n) or O(nlogn) space can solve this problem?  

I have a idea:  
**Record the "current position" of every line and loop.**  

But I don't know how to implement it.  

Is there an implement or other ideas?
num=`awk \'END{print NF}\' file.txt`\nfor i in `seq 1 $num`;do cut -d \' \' -f $i file.txt|xargs; done
seq 1 $(head -1 file.txt | wc -w) | xargs -I \'{}\' bash -c "cut -d \'"\' \'"\' -f {} file.txt| xargs"

I'm not sure why the simple recursive algorithm would work. It replaces every pair of "++" in the original string with "--" and ask the questions: can my opponent win? 

However, the canWin() function returns true if the current player is "guarantee a win", and it returns false if the current player cannot guarantee a win - meaning the current player might win or lose depending on the action of the opponent. If this is the case, why algorithm like [this][1] works?



 


  [1]: https://leetcode.com/discuss/64291/share-my-java-backtracking-solution

"+++++++++"

Player a plays: "+--++++++"
Player b plays: "+--+--+++"
Player a plays: "+--+--+--"
Player b's turn, he has no move to play. So (starting) player A wins.

why does this testcase return false?

Player a plays: "+--++++++"
Player b plays: "+--++--++"
Player a plays: "+------++"
Player b plays: "+--------"
Now player a has no move.

You have to account for turn switching.  
If A plays +++--++++, B can play in ++++ half to lose in that half, but grab the turn to play first on the +++ side where it wins.

Can anyone please confirm why the expected result for the following test case is TRUE?
"++++-++++++"

My code failed because my alg is giving 'false', but I am a little confused why the OJ gives 'TRUE'. No matter what the first player does, the second player can find a way to eventually win the game. Am I missing some critical info here?
On both sides 1st player can make the 2nd player win or lose depending on the 1st player\'s strategy.  Losing on one side gives an opportunity to win on the other one...

I\'m also confused about it. I think this case is false. "Garanteed to win" means as long as the first person did the first move, no matter what moves were done after it, the first person will win, right? I don\'t think it\'s true for this case. Could anyone tell me the reason to be true? Thank you.

Update:

Thanks  bravejia for pointing out one case which was missing in my original post.

the winning strategy is that after flip, two strings are still both can-win-or-lose strings. Basically, starting player can choose not to make decision in his first turn.

Take "++++-++++++" as an example again:

A: ++++---++++

This will leave B with two both can-win-or-lose strings. And there will be no further subset can-win-or-lose strings. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Orignal Post:

I think  "++++-++++++" is a lose. And here is why.

Both ++++ and ++++++ are can-win-or-lose strings. A can-win-or-lose string is a case where first player can choose if he wants to win or lose. 
For example, in case of ++++, first player can choose flip middle two to win, or to flip first two to lose.

So in case of two can-win-or-lose strings, or even number of can-win-or-lose strings, second player can always adjust his strategy based on first player's move. 

Take "++++-++++++" as an example, 

If A choose to win "++++", B can win by winning"++++++".

A: +--+-++++++

B: +--+-++--++

If A choose to lose "++++", B can win by losing"++++++".

A: --++-++++++

B: --++-+--+++

B can have same strategy If A choose to flip second  can-win-or-lose strings first.

So  "++++-++++++" is a lose. Feel free to correct me if I am wrong.
I was using Java and replaced StringBuilder with char array and reduce the running time from 137ms to 11ms. But I don\'t think StringBuilder is that slow
